Seems there is a lot of confusing sentence construction in that message, or=
 it doesn't carry the right terminology, can't quite say.

Resource Identif=
ier: A URI.
Resource: A concept / temporal mapping that has a Resource Iden=
tifier
Representation: A binary stream that contains the state of a Resourc=
e at the time of retrieval.

If you move a representation between two URIs,=
 you have changed neither the resource (the two things identified by the UR=
Is) nor the identifiers. You've changed the state of the resource, and that=
's it.

Just because you move the representation from /posts/latest to /pos=
t/nearlylatest and assign a new represetnation to /posts/latest, you have n=
ot changed what the resource is or how it is identified, you just changed t=
he state (the entity in this case, where entity =3D body + metadata, which =
is what we call the representation).

Hi Adriano.
Yes, interesting catch. The guideline m=
ay misguide to one of the options you mention, that I dislike a lot: URL Te=
mplates. That makes the server lose control of the URL space, as it it is f=
orced to follow a strict construction that also exposes resource informatio=
n.

I may make a difference between a resource Identifier and a simple enti=
ty identifier. The resource identifier is always the URL, that may change o=
ver time. We create a resource using an entity (pure information) and it is=
 stored somewhere and a URI is assigned to it. If you have the entity id li=
ke the UUID, the only hope you have is searching the web space for a resour=
ce that may be representing it. You can have more than one, actually, and t=
here should be a way in the app to get to it (searching is the normal optio=
n here).

So, the questions is not about the client finding the URL structu=
re, but of the client finding the search service. Say, we can have a link i=
n the welcome page that says "Find item by ID". Simple.

William Martinez.
